title: Are there possible solutions to the hard problem of consciousness? Is there a theory that may explain how the physical characteristics of our brain produce a sense of experience? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Hard Problem has three distinct components. How does phenomenal consciousness (hereafter “phenomenality”) fit into physics?Why does it happen in the brain, and thus, where else might it happen?What is its causal or explanatory role? We seem to be able to subtract it from our picture of the world and leave the world unchanged (except for thinking and talking about it).This is new: There’s no understanding the field without realizing that the problem proper divides into the first two parts. Consider the three big names. On the first question, John Searle and David Chalmers are broadly in agreement and both think Daniel Dennett couldn’t be more wrong. On the second question, however, Chalmers and Dennett are completely in agreement and Searle thinks they’re both completely wrong. (Footnote 3 on Searle’s position has another such example.) There are four distinct viable ideas for answering question 1. And, no, that phenomenality is simply an emergent property of the brain’s function is not one of them. Making it emergent is option 4, but it requires rewriting physics literally from the bottom up. It’s the most radical solution, not the least. Question 2 is much more muddled. Certain ideas are compatible with one another—for instance, you can give one answer for color experiences , and another for pain—and none is truly satisfying. Question 3—the problem of “mental causation”—is philosophically the most important, and seems to be 100% insoluble. Everyone regards the notion that phenomenality is causally, explanatorily, and behaviorally irrelevant to be obviously unacceptable, but no one has a clue as how to actually make it otherwise. And now the details … I’ll try to do a chunk of this each evening and try to finish by Sunday. Question 1: How does phenomenality fit into physics? There’s no remotely satisfying way to put the four viable options in order. What I think makes the most sense is to go from the least radical, in terms of changing physics, to the most. But that also means starting with the most obscure! Ideopsychism (the term is my own, and is meant to contrast with “panpsychism”) proposes that phenomenality is instantiated by new physical entities that are not part of the Standard Model of physics, but can be integrated with it. In every version I can conceive of, phenomenality is a fundamental property of these entities. Ideopsychism historically comes in three flavors. There’s the overly vague version I just gave. There is particle ideopsychism (option 1 in our taxonomy), which proposes that the unknown entities are particles and their associated fields, and there is field ideopsychism (option 2), which proposes that phenomenality is a field that is not part of the Standard Model but has no corresponding particle. (Yes, technically this is field-only ideopsychism, but I think this terminology is clear nevertheless.) Field ideopsychism was proposed in 1962 by one of the most eminent philosophers of the half-century, Wilfrid Sellars, in one of his two most famous papers, “Philosophy and the Scientific Image of Man.” By proposing a field without a particle, he sought to avoid what has become known as the “grain problem,” the mystery of how phenomenality can be so very unitary in nature if it originates from a large group of physical entities. [1] It was ignored. I invented particle ideopsychism in 1998 and had the idea enthusiastically vetted as workable by one of the world’s most eminent philosophers of physics, David Z. Albert (here’s that story). I first presented it in public in 1999. William G. Lycan labelled Sellars’ version “outrageous” in a 2003 paper and went on to characterize ideopsychism in general as “absurd” and “grotesque.” This happened to be in the lead paper in the book Chomsky and his Critics, and Chomsky strongly defended ideopsychism as reasonable in his reply. And since new physics historically has always meant new particles, I take this to mean that Chomsky specifically regards particle ideopsychism as a worthy class of solution. And you’ve got to like an idea that both Noam Chomsky and David Albert think is viable! Particle ideopsychism, to my knowledge, first appears in the literature in a 2013 paper by Berit Brogaard of the University of Miami. [2] I encountered it in her paper “In Search of Mentons: Panpsychism, Physicalism, and the Missing Link” in the 2017 collection Panpsychism: Contemporary Perspectives (yes, she got to propose her alternative to panpsychism in a collection of papers supporting and exploring it). She doesn’t seem to be aware that Chomsky has her back! For the other reasons that particle ideopsychism is our best best, you’ll have to wait for my book. Field ideopsychism has had only one other supporter that I know of, and he’s a recent convert to the position. But like Sellars, he’s also profoundly eminent: John Searle. Sellars may or may not explain why and/or how he thinks fields he called “sensa” are produced in the brain. I have to read his further work on his theory, and he’s a notoriously unclear and obscure writer. Searle has phenomenality as a field produced by an ontologically unique type of emergence, which (arbitrarily, I believe) combines the features he needs from ordinary (“weak”) emergence and “strong” emergence. [3] He’s adamant that such fields emerge as the result of the brain’s neurobiology, but I don’t believe he’s ever explained why or how that might be (his latest ideas are in a journal paper which has not yet been collected or appeared online). I think that field ideopsychism is highly dubious—the particle version has all the advantages and none of the drawbacks—but it’s not demonstrably false, and it obviously has been supported by smart people. Next: the two remaining viable options. They are both versions of the already-mentioned panpsychism. [1] Yes, you have to be unschooled in physics to not realize that any field solves the grain problem, even if it originates in a particle. [2] I think that’s the case. The price of the book where the paper appears has recently dropped at Amazon to $114. [3] From weak emergence, he grabs the idea that phenomenality follows with metaphysical necessity from its physical substrates, and that it therefore has the same causal role. But he vehemently denies that it is thus in any way identical to its substrates, or can be reduced to them, since that’s a position that’s easy to falsify. That phenomenality cannot be reduced to (or deduced from) its physical substrates is a key characteristic of strong emergence—which if fully embraced, however, would make phenomenality metaphysically contingent (optional) and causally irrelevant. This same “take what you need and leave the rest” strategy is also used by the position called non-reductive materialism—but its advocates justify it as a consequence of the truth of functionalism. And Searle is the world’s leading anti-functionalist—that’s what his famous “Chinese Room” thought experiment argues. Strong emergence is a dualist solution while weak emergence is monist—and Searle argues that that distinction is not relevant. (I just got the relationship between this claim and the fact that his solution combines elements of monism and dualism—and that’s the reason I write these answers!)

The hard problem is the difficulty in describing ‘mind’ in the language of science. The scientific literature doesn’t yet include a theory of sentience, doesn’t contain a description of the physics of the observer. The physical characteristics of our brain produce something to experience. The perceiver of that experience possesses a faculty for experiencing that which it perceives. Some argue that the capacity to have experience is a capacity of the brain. Some argue that causality goes the other way, argue that consciousness somehow creates something that the perceiver can experience. Like ideas pursue causality and never really get anywhere in that pursuit. Instead, I abandon causality and use relativity, complementarity, and symmetry to construct a model of consciousness; and from that model, a new conservation law is derived. Relativity allows causality to be abandoned as the principle connecting the perceiver to the perceived. Relativity allows us to instead describe mind and body as bound via the acausal connecting principle of complementarity. Regarding science as a quest for symmetry, see Science: the Quest for Symmetry | 3 Quarks Daily, written by Quora contributor Yohan John, last two paragraphs of that article: Metaphysical speculations about the “fundamental” nature of the universe often posit the existence of a basic substance: something that exists at all times and in all places, uniform and unchanging. The symmetry perspective seems to preclude the scientific discovery of any such universal invariant. In order to discover a symmetry, we need an underlying asymmetry — a measuring stick or reference. If we take seriously the idea that science is symmetry, we can ask ourselves what the underlying asymmetry might be. What is the ultimate reference frame — the messy backdrop against which the neat symmetries of science show up in stark relief? Can we conceive of anything that is fundamentally asymmetrical? I can only offer some wild speculation. There seem to be three grand metaphysical concepts that no one can really agree on: existence, time, and mind. The symmetry perspective does not really shed much light on these imponderables, but it might allow us to link them to each other. Symmetry is immunity to a possible change. What exists — what is visible through the Symmetry Spectacles — must be susceptible to change. Change and time are thoroughly entangled. To measure a change is to compare two points in time. But to compare two points in time, something must be measurably changed. And it seems to me that in order to measure anything at all there must be a mind — a subjectivity that is restlessly aware of the passage of time and the accretion of changes. Perhaps the mind is the fundamental asymmetry: the process that is never quite the same from one moment to the next. John’s speculation in the 2nd paragraph isn’t quite correct. Here’s why. A “measuring stick or reference” is not a description that fits the idea of asymmetry. Instead, a measuring stick or reference ordinarily is conceived as being a standard body of reference, a fixed (continuous, persistent) rod against which variation is measured in space-time. Physics at root measures with a rod and a clock. The face of a clock shows changes in its hand’s positions. The hands of a clock represent variation and we discern that the face of the clock does not change while the hands of the clock sweep around in a circle. The face of the clock is like a symmetry against which change is measured. A rod is used to measure variation. Conversely, variation distinguishes invariance as a fixed standard body of reference against which variation is measured. That’s relativity, and a standard body of reference must be fixed stationary, unchanging. That’s because if the measuring rod—the fixed standard body of reference—varies, it becomes part of the variation it would be used to measure. Hence, a variation can’t be used to measure itself, not being independent and fixed. Relativity tells us that motion of an independent object cannot be measured except in relation to and independent invariable. A ruler is independent of the object of its measurement. Conversely, an object of measurement must be independent of the object used to measure it. So let’s rewrite John’s first paragraph from above. My rewrite: Metaphysical speculations about the “fundamental” nature of the universe often posit the existence of a basic substance: something that exists at all times and in all places, uniform and unchanging. The symmetry perspective doesn’t seem to preclude the scientific discovery of any such universal invariant. In order to discover a symmetry, we need an underlying asymmetry — an independent variation as a reference against which an independent invariance may be discerned. If we take seriously the idea that science is symmetry, we can ask ourselves what the underlying symmetry might be. For instance, we discovered that energy is conserved by measuring variation and then accounting for the work-products resulting from that variation. We found that the quantity of energy is unaffected by change. The invariance of the rod allowed us to do an accounting of the energy involved over a duration of a variation. That accounting showed that energy was conserved, did not change despite change. Hence, we discovered a symmetry in nature using our science. We can ask a broader question. We can ask this: What is the ultimate reference frame — the messy backdrop against which the neat symmetries of science show up in stark relief? Can we conceive of anything that is fundamentally asymmetrical? John recognizes that one must identify a variation, an asymmetry, in order to identify a phenomenal that does not vary in relation to that asymmetry. Variation distinguishes invariance because in contrast to variation, invariance doesn’t change at all. So in science, when an invariance—symmetry—is not known to us, we use a rod and a clock to find it via an accounting that such instrumentation allows. That is science’s search for symmetry, that’s the symmetry perspective that is a productive perspective in science. When a symmetry isn’t known, then from exploring asymmetry, symmetry may be discovered using a rod and a clock. John then asks what might be the ultimate “…messy backdrop against which the neat symmetries of science show up in stark relief.” The ultimate fundamental asymmetry is said to have begun with a big bang, an event from which the ultimate messy backdrop of the universe emerged. It is our investigation of that fundamental asymmetry that has revealed its neat symmetries. Hence, his is the wrong question because we already know the answer. The question is, what is the ultimate symmetry that we have as yet to discover? With a rewrite of John’s second paragraph above, we will have an answer. My rewrite: I can only offer some wild speculation. There seem to be three grand metaphysical concepts that no one can really agree on: existence, space-time, and mind. Science uses variability of objects in space-time to discover hitherto unknown symmetries. Science’s symmetry spectacles play around with variation in order to discover a phenomenal that does not change and is therefore a symmetry, an invariance, a sameness, a repetition. Relativity informs us that it takes a variation—an asymmetry—in order for a neat symmetry to show itself to science in stark relief. Relativity also informs us that the converse is also true. Namely, in order for variation to be measured, a variation must be set in relation to at least one independent invariant. That invariant, a rod, makes measurements of change possible. Consequently, there is another set of symmetry spectacles to consider. Namely, it is also from a known phenomenal symmetry that variation itself can be discovered. That alternative symmetry perspective does shed light light on the imponderables of existence, space-time, and mind. It allows us to link them to each other. Here’s how. Our mind observes change. Therefore, by relativity, the mind, in order to observe change, must also contain an independent invariant against which change may be discerned. To measure a change is to compare two points in time. But to compare two points in time, something must be measurably changed in its relation to something that does not change. In our mind, what might that invariant be? Symmetry is immunity to a possible change. What is it that exists as an independent invariable, what is it in ‘mind’ that is insusceptible to change? Have you guessed the answer? Because with our conversely prepared symmetry spectacles, we should already know of that phenomenal symmetry. When you already know the symmetry, there’s no reason to look for that symmetry by measuring and then accounting for variation. Instead, variation’s existence serves to confirm that an known invariant is an invariant because it is only from that invariance as a point for measurement that change can be physically discerned. If there is one thing of which we may be certain, it’s that we can make discriminations well enough to just take that faculty for granted. From 18th century philosopher David Hume’s essay Of Personal Identity: There are some philosophers who imagine we are every moment intimately conscious of what we call our self; that we feel its existence and its continuance in existence; and are certain, beyond the evidence of a demonstration, both of its perfect identity and simplicity. The strongest sensation, the most violent passion, say they, instead of distracting us from this view, only fix it the more intensely, and make us consider their influence on self either by their pain or pleasure. To attempt a further proof of this were to weaken its evidence; since no proof can be derived from any fact of which we are so intimately conscious; nor is there anything of which we can be certain if we doubt of this. In that essay, Hume describes two senses of self. One that varies along with variable circumstances. And one sense of self that is a sense of it’s own continuity. Personal identity is described by Hume to be “I”-ness, a simple sameness always equal to itself, an identity, a personal identity, distinct and invariant over the duration of a lifetime. That’s the fundamental symmetry, ‘you’, that makes the variation in our stream of consciousness interpretable as change. That which is interpreted is the fundamental asymmetry against which the neat symmetries of nature reveal. That according to the principle of relativity. That is an in principle an identification of personal identity, not ‘consciousness’, as being a fundamental just as much as are fundamental charge, mass, and space-time. I develop that idea into an experimentally verified theory of sentience in organisms, develop that idea here: Charles Wood's answer to Will there ever be a tool to figure out whether another living being is conscious or not? There’s a shorter presentation of that idea here: Charles Wood's answer to What are the examples of objective reality? From that, it is clear from science that there cannot be a theory to explain how the brain produces a faculty for having experience. Instead, that faculty is inherent in the ego, and the ego is inherent in all life. That theory is formed of a datum, two principles, and a deduction. It leaves us to wonder, what is personal identity (Hume’s use of that term intended) that it existed independent of and concomitant with the other building blocks of life. It isn’t ‘consciousness’ that is fundamental. Instead, it is the ego, personal identity, that is fundamental and independent of that which we call physicality. There is no good reason to not just allow ‘ego’ as physicality although we aren’t used to thinking of our core self as physicality. Relativity says it is, so deal.

For me these are arbitrary artifacts that are unnecessary. There is no such things as a hard problem and soft problem. Chalmers asks how is it that physical phenomenon and experience which are physically processed give rise to such a rich inner life. It is done by abstraction which is one of the operations of the intellect, the faculty of thought, and transcends the life of mere sense. Information from reality, extra-mental life, is the source of phenomena and is known after the mode of our knowing which is immaterial. In other words this entire operation is spiritual and transcends sense experience. Brute animals are awake and alert to particular events but are not self aware. That belongs to rational beings and this is man who judges, willfully focuses and pays attention. judges, understands, reasons, forms concepts and syllogisms etc. And who senses and knows and understands. The difficulty arises in the denial of a spiritual soul, a simple form, which unites with the body to form the person. The admission of this brings about many insurmountable difficulties to many. Chalmers states that perhaps the hard problem will never be solved. I have no problem with its solution. This rich inner life, this subjective aspect, is the Ego, the “ I “ which experiences through the senses the extra mental world , the “ I “ of course is the person. The problem cannot and will never be solved without the admission that we have faculties that transcend sense and matter, that the brain has its proper place in the whole scheme of things but it cannot reflect or introspect because it cannot turn back on itself, and that the “ I “ possesses the fullness of existence,and this is neither body alone nor soul alone but body and soul. The easy problems cannot be solved by physical processes alone either. I think “ Aquinas on Human Self-Knowledge “ by Therese Cory Scarpelli puts all of this to rest, completely.

What a wonderful question. I have thought about this question in one form or another since I first realized that I was conscious of my own thoughts. This was somewhere around age 10, and questions like this are the reason I chose a career in psychology. Fair warning: It’s a big question so my answer is not short. A two-paragraph answer just won’t cut it here. So, my take on the so-called “hard problem” of consciousness, as posed by David Chalmers & others, is that it isn’t a question that science can address. It’s off in that fuzzy philosophical realm that questions why certain things *feel* the way they do, or how to account for particular qualia (why blue *looks* blue rather than some other color), or why there is any sense of experience at all. Rather than get tangled up in issues such as these, I believe that the best approach is to start with what we know of consciousness, lay it all out on the table, and see if there are any parts missing. Here is what I have learned about consciousness. It takes place in the cortex, and seems to be focused mostly in the prefrontal cortex. Its contents are limited to events that take place in the cortex, so all the subcortical events are invisible to it. A further restriction is that in order for something to be conscious, it has to have a certain minimal extent in space and time. Localized events in cortex that proceed normally, such as the assembly of visual features into larger and larger composite perceptions, do not reach consciousness. Neither do events that occur too quickly. There isn’t a fixed lower threshold for consciousness, but it’s clearly on the order of 50 to 100 milliseconds (100 msec is a tenth of a second). One more attribute worth noting is that consciousness is “single-threaded.” We are only conscious of a single core process, such as solving a problem or making a decision. Everything else is either unconscious or, in the case of the previous thought and the next one, at the “edges” of consciousness as they move in and out of focus. So, put those attributes together and what do we have that can be stated in scientific terms? Simply this: What we call consciousness is the prefrontal cortex monitoring and integrating the high-level activities taking place throughout the cortex. Nothing more. Nothing less. Now we come to the fun part. How is it that we can be conscious of being conscious? We are obviously aware of being conscious; otherwise the question you asked could never even come up. So do we need another level of monitoring to explain that? No. The process of monitoring and integrating cortical processes includes the prefrontal cortex and hence the monitoring process itself. And, of course, the awareness of the monitoring is also within the scope of the monitoring, so it, too, is consciousness. It’s a little like the facing mirrors in a barber shop: we see an image of ourselves that contains the image we are seeing, which includes a smaller image, and so on. But I don’t think it goes many levels in the brain. My guess is that three levels are enough: We are aware of what’s happening in our brains, we are aware of that awareness, and we can be sufficiently aware of that higher-level awareness to analyze it over time and wonder about it. To sum up, I think that consciousness is the brain monitoring its own processes, and that this self-reflective aspect produces an experience that has real depth and power for us. Now, this still doesn’t say why the brain has *any* experience of itself. But trying to imagine a brain like ours that *doesn’t* have an awareness of its own processes just leads you to what philosophers call the zombie problem. If you can imagine people walking around, doing the things people do everyday, but having no awareness of their own existence, then you’re basically saying that zombies –unconscious automata – are a real possibility. But if you ask one of these zombies what her thoughts and feelings are, she will give you perfectly adequate answers. In which case she wouldn’t really be a zombie, would she? In short, I don’t believe there really is a “hard problem” with consciousness. I have a theory of consciousness that tells me what it is, how it evolved, what it does, and why it seems so deep and self-reflective. If there is still a problem to be solved – and many philosophers maintain that there is – then I have no idea how to even frame it in scientific terms. By the way, I put this question in the same box as the classic mind-body problem. Once you know enough about the brain, you realize that the mind is the activity of the brain. Nothing more, nothing less. What we call mind is simply the private, inner view the brain has of itself. The brain has no physical senses so it can’t perceive the reality of its own physical nature, so it feels like it’s abstract and detached from the physical brain. But to think it is a non-physical entity that is separate from that brain is to confuse a process with an entity, creating a “problem” that simply doesn’t exist. I suspect that the “hard problem” of consciousness will go the way of the mind-body problem once we get a better handle on the underlying processes.

Notice that all theories are based on ideas (number, form and meaning). Plainly, ideas are dimensionless, without substance or duration or any discernible qualities. They are simply Known. Could any idea exist that is not Known? Plainly, Knowing-ideas is a facet of Consciousness… whatever it is. All rigorous scientific theories are ideas about the observed world expressed as mathematical models (ideas) of the behaviour of mathematically defined ‘objects’, such as fields and sub-atomic particles, etc (more ideas). We say a theory is valid when the behaviour of the theoretical objects reliably maps the behaviour of observed objects. All ‘emergence’ is about emergent ‘behaviour’. Behaviour mapping behaviour and behaviour emerging from behaviour is hardly surprising! Plainly, there is a correlation between observed behaviour of bodies and brains, the theories that map the behaviour, and Awareness of things and events. However, theories say nothing about the essence or cause of observation, or the nature of observed objects. They say nothing about Consciousness. No theory ever can, for no idea (about reality) can be reality. Seeing-colours is real. It not remotely like any ‘idea’ (theory) about it. If it was possible to devise a theory of reality that was real, the theory itself would See! Can you imagine a ‘colour’ being if there is nothing to See it? What about a feeling? Could a feeling exist that is not Felt? How could any sensation exist that is not Sensed? Plainly, Sensing-sensations (colours, odours, flavours, feelings and sounds) is also a facet of Consciousness… whatever it is. From a scientific perspective, ‘light waves’ are said to be the cause of Seeing-colours. Yet, ‘light’ is invisible. It is a small part of the electro-magnetic radiation (EMR) spectrum. From a scientific perspective, ‘EMR’ ceases to exist the moment it hits the retina. Only very specific wavelengths result in a electro-chemical impulse along the optic nerves to the visual cortex at the back of the head, where (according to science) colours appear in the absence of light. On this view, there is no ‘little person’ inside the head looking out through the eyes into the theorised material world. All the signals are from the ‘outside’ to ‘in’. Even more astounding, on this view of the ‘emergence of colour inside the head’, the coloured patterns must perceive themselves as separate objects, separate from the observer! It is as though the patterns of colour on a computer screen (that represent objects and creatures in a ‘game-world’) could see themselves, not as the patterns on the screen but as separate objects being observed from the perspective of one of the characters in the game! Plainly, every apparent object is ‘illusory’. It appears to be something it is not: coloured patterns (and other sensations) appearing to be ‘things’ and ‘events’ as meaning (ideas) are associated with the sensory images. Rather than theorise, simply notice the visual field. Look straight ahead. Notice the visual field appears like a circle with an indefinite edge. Without moving the head or eyes, notice that ‘beyond’ the ‘edge ’ is neither black nor white… simply nothing. Notice ‘your’ body is not apparent. Now look down. Notice the body appears as a foreshortened image distorted by the ‘laws of perspective’, with only the front of the torso and limbs apparent… but no head. Where the head should be, the whole world appears, or at least that bit perceivable from the perspective of the person you seem to be. This is called The Single Eye of God. It is the Eye of Consciousness… the only Eye there is. Everything appears in it, and no where else. It has no discernible dimension, or substance, or duration. Far from Consciousness being inside a body, plainly the body is an appearance in it, along with everything else. ‘Wait’, I hear you say, ‘I can feel my head’. But notice, no ‘feeling’ or ‘idea’ (that the feeling is my head) is an actual head. Awareness is self-evident. It is this capacity to Sense-sensations and Know-ideas. Don’t take my word for it. See for yourself… Notice that the patterns of colours in the visual field form 2D projections of Known 3D objects - distorted by the laws of perspective. Take a cube. This is Known to have six sides at right angles that are all the same size and shape that never change. Notice no such object has ever been seen! Each apparent cube shows only 1–3 sides that constantly change apparent size and shape, depending on the viewpoint of the observer. Notice the ‘apparent changing object’ is seen as a cube, only as the ‘unchanging idea of cube’ is associated with the image. A thing that changes size and shape cannot be a thing that does not change… it can only appear so. Such appearance is by definition an illusion. Or, hold the thumb close to the eye. Notice it appears to be larger than other objects Known to be orders of magnitude bigger than it. A thing that is smaller than other things cannot also be larger than them… it can only appear so. Such appearance is by definition an illusion Or, take the sides of a long straight road that are Known to be parallel. Plainly, they appear to converge towards the horizon. A thing that converges cannot also be a thing that is parallel- it can only appear so as the unchanging idea of ‘parallel’ is associated with the changing image. Such appearance is by definition an illusion. The same that now Sees these words being written is the same that now seems to be reading them. All that differs is the sensations and ideas together forming the body, thoughts, feelings and surroundings apparent in Consciousness. Now it appears ‘I am the writer’. And now it appears ‘I am the reader’. As one experience appears, there are no other experiences happening any where or any when else, as there is no where but here and no when but now. Science, Introspection and Religion all concur: the apparent world is a world of illusion. This is not to deny the ‘objective world’ as mapped by science. Only to recognise that such world is not separate from Consciousness. Nor is it to say that the ‘material world’ is identical with Consciousness. Panpsychism is just another idea. Though no idea can be like reality, rather than think in ‘material’ terms, think of the visual field more like a screen within which the ‘objective world’ is made apparent; and the ‘laws of nature’ discovered through science as more like a map of the software that runs a game-world. While the objects on the screen (in the visual field) obey the laws of the game-world (the laws of nature); in either case (in the game-world or in the objective world) there are no ‘real’ objects (apart from the Known forms and meaning that define them). There are only the rules (laws of nature) and the images created by the rules (laws of nature) on the screen (in the visual field)… and the ideas-Known that that give the forms meaning. Better yet, drop all ideas about what Consciousness is and how it works, and simply observe what unfolds. Science and technology are both wonders of Consciousness, no less than the natural world. Through them, the unimaginable depth and breadth of this universe is made manifest… though it is like looking through a key hole :) Consciousness is infinitely greater than this apparent universe, though not in dimension or duration. How can this be? Notice that the number, form and meaning of every experience depends upon the ideas associated with the sensory images that manifest the experience. Notice that no idea can ever change, for if it did it would be a different idea and not the idea it is. Notice each idea takes its meaning by reference to other ideas that take their meaning from still more ideas that take their meaning from the unchanging self-referential set of all ideas-Known. This Knowing-all-ideas-as-one is called: Omniscience. Plainly, Consciousness contains the ideas of all possible universes perceived as sensory images within its own Awareness from all possible perspectives - each in their turn… as One’s ‘nightly’ dreams attest. Just as plainly, ‘I am conscious, yet I am not aware of knowing everything’! So, how can Consciousness be All-Knowing and not Know it? But notice… ‘Ant’ Until this word appeared was there any Awareness of Knowing or not-Knowing the idea associated with the word? Plainly, the meaning is not in the word, else it would be impossible for one word to have different meanings, or different words to have the same meaning. Words have meaning only as ideas are associated with them. What is true of ‘words’ is true of all ‘things’. Until the ideas (that give number, form and meaning to the appearance) are imaged via sensations there is no Awareness of the ideas-Known. This apparent lack of knowledge (ignorance) permits the appearance of each ‘life’ (as it is experienced), to be as if it is the only life ever lived. Whilesoever it appears ‘I am this person’, the ‘person I seem to be’ has no ‘free will’. Say ‘you’ choose for a reason, then it is not you but the reason that chooses. Had the reason been different the choice would be different. Or perhaps the choice was not based on reason but resulted from the pull of desire. Do ‘you’ manufacture your desires before they arise, deciding to manifest, say, the desire for chocolate, or does desire simply arise unbidden? If the desire had been different the choice would have been different. Only spontaneous action free of reason or desire may be said to be truly free… unless it is the result of antecedent causes. If ‘you’ give no thought to an action and are not driven by desire, still the body acts according to the dictates of the universal laws that govern it. Whichever way you look at it, despite appearances, no human possesses free will. Consciousness on the other hand is entirely free. It is unbounded, dimensionless and timeless. It never changes. All change is apparent only… arising spontaneously within its own Awareness. Within its non-dual perfection every imperfect duality is perfectly realized… now and now and now. These words will be read from the perspective of very few people. No person will ever realise their import. Realization is not an act of any person. It is an act of Grace. Any meaning attached to these words is not it. These words are like a signpost to a waterfall. To recognise the reality they reference, one must ‘attend’ to where they point. Where they point is ‘out’ of this page towards the Clear Silent Awareness now perceiving these words, and back to the appearances that are one with it. What it is, is impossible to say. That it is is plain. Plainly, Consciousness is… Sensing-sensations (colours, odours, flavours, feelings and sounds) and Knowing-ideas (number, form and meaning) with the Power to manifest sensory images within its own Awareness in accord with ideas to create the appearance of ‘my body’ and ‘my thoughts’ and ‘my feelings’ and ‘my surroundings’… as in a dream. This is Thou And ‘life’ just carries on… Michael Haines's answer to What does it feel like to be enlightened?

Yes this theory exists. It attacks less directly the problem of consciousness than the very construction of reality. But this is how it derives its great efficacy about consciousness. Indeed, if you reject the irreducible dualism of matter / consciousness, then consciousness must be an extension of the organization of reality. Current neuroscience does not make the connection. Why ? Like other sciences, it is concerned with systems, in this case neural networks: their functioning is decrypted with increasing precision. Which in no way explains why these neural excitations produce consciousness. Why do they succeed under a skull and not in an abdomen? Yet we have several hundred million neurons associated with the intestine. Amazing properties are not exclusive to neurons. In parallel it may seem surprising that a coil begins to magnetize surrounding metal objects simply because it is traversed by electrons. Where does this 'magnetic field' come from, an emerging phenomenon equivalent to consciousness for the coil? This last problem is easier to solve. The knowledge of the fine organization of the electrons and the direction of their spin explains the magnetic field. Electronic current and magnetism are two neighboring levels of organization. Their relationships are known. Yet they keep their independence. Magnetism rests on the electronic current but is not reducible to it. It follows its own organizational rules. The reality is thus discontinuous in a neglected dimension: that of its organization. Monism is reconciled with dualism by being a multitude of crossings to complexity. Their independence is based on those of the systems themselves: the elementary time of interactions and the energies involved differ by several orders of magnitude. These levels are invisible to each other. A one-level dynamic system is a stable element in the next. This approach applied to neural networks removes the hard problem of consciousness. Indeed networks form a hierarchy similar to that of matter. Neural groups are systems with relative independence. Their simultaneous excitations symbolize concepts, both evolutionary and 'elements' for the organization of higher concepts. A bright spot on the retina becomes line with the others, the lines become face, etc. Consciousness is formed of the highest concepts, 'experienced' as the superimposition of all these underlying organizations, including that of the physical support (the biological constitution of neurons). This theory makes it possible to say that an artificial intelligence simulating the conscious concepts by algorithms would experience something, but not the same thing as a biological intelligence because of its different support. Why is this theory, which I have simplified to the extreme, not better recognized? As much as it is easy to spread fake news, which target common and popular concepts in our minds, it is difficult to make known a theory that few people can understand. The specialists of a subject protect themselves from gurus and whimsical publications by agreeing to read ... only the specialists of the subject. Without academic title, impossible to publish. And to be criticized ... So it is probably a theory that will take a long time to leave a circle of friends.

“We are the universe experiencing itself.”(Carl Sagan) The Hard Problem of consciousness arises within the conceptual framework of scientific materialism. Plausibly, the mathematical formalism of our best description of the natural world describes fields of insentience. This assumption isn’t explicitly stated in any textbook of organic chemistry or formulation of the axioms of quantum mechanics. Rather, the assumption that the intrinsic nature of the physical is non-experiential is a philosophical intuition treated as too obvious to need stating explicitly. Critically, it’s not a scientific discovery. Dropping the suppressed premise also dissolves the Hard Problem as framed. One may or may not take non-materialist physicalism seriously as a solution to the Hard Problem of consciousness. I struggle. Either way, the track-record of human intuition is spectacularly bad and can’t be trusted at all. The second part of your question needs unpacking. What do we mean by “the physical characteristics of the brain”? If perceptual direct realism is true, then the gross characteristics of the physical universe are self-evident. Although the invisible microworld of quantum theory is an enigma even to physicists, the shared public macroworld is a brute fact of our existence. Therefore, we can directly inspect a surgically-exposed lump of neural tissue on a hospital operating table. If the patient is merely locally anaesthetised prior to surgery, stimulation of clusters of neurons with microelectrodes elicits reports of experiences ranging from e.g. fleeting hisses and speckles of colour to complex visual experiences of lifelike persons external to the patient’s body-image (cf. Opening the heads of living patients). How can mere patterns of neuronal firings generate first-person conscious experience? The “explanatory gap” seems unbridgeable. Subjective experience is irreducible to physical facts. And the story gets worse. Perceptual direct realism gives rise to insoluble mysteries such as the binding problem in neuroscience and the measurement problem in quantum mechanics. However, the entire conceptual framework of perceptual direct realism is false. Most probably, inferential realism about mind-independent reality is true (cf. “Philosophy’s biggest mistake”). Compare dreaming and waking consciousness. When you examine a surgically-exposed lump of neural porridge on an operating table in a dream, the brain that you see in front of your body-image is internal to the phenomenal world-simulation run by your skull-bound mind. When you are awake and examine a surgically-exposed lump of neural porridge on an operating table, the brain you see in front of your body-image is also internal to the phenomenal world-simulation run by your skull-bound mind. Let’s here discount scepticism or solipsism; they are sterile. Unlike dreamworlds, the properties of your awake world-simulation causally covary with structural-relational properties of matter and energy in the theoretically-inferred external world. Hence inferential realism. Yet “perception” as ordinarily understood is a pre-scientific myth. Indirectly, the local environment partly selects the properties of one’s phenomenal world-simulation, but peripheral nervous inputs don’t create the phenomena they select. In outline, quantum physics explains the emergence of differentially robust, quasi-classical, dynamically stable patterns (“neurons”) from underlying quantum bedrock via environmentally-induced decoherence. Hence the metaphorical hardware on which our phenomenal world-simulations run. But lumps of neural porridge (“brains”) are an artefact of a false theory of perception. Provocatively, what we perceive as “brains” don’t exist outside our consciousness. More soberly expressed, the natural world supports structures partly functionally akin to brains and partly functionally akin to neurons, but the neural porridge of perceptual naïve realism is mind-dependent. Consequently, the only direct evidence one has about the intrinsic nature of the physical is the nature of the tiny part of the physical world one instantiates, namely one’s own conscious mind. On this story, the mathematical apparatus of quantum field theory describes fields of sentience. Crazy? Yes. But empirically adequate. Try telling a physicist or chemist that their conceptual scheme is empirically inadequate, and you’ll get a stony look. Science works. Yet what would leave the technological successes of science a miracle isn’t the falsity of materialism, but rather the falsity of monistic physicalism. Physicalism, not materialism, gives science its explanatory and predictive power. None of the weird ideas explored here are inconsistent with the mathematical formalism of Standard Model. None of the weird ideas explored here add to the formalism of modern physics. Contrast such theoretical conservativism with panpsychism or a consciousness-induced “collapse of the wavefunction”. So I think testing physicalism will be the key – not in a high-energy particle accelerator, but the mind-brain. Is the partial “structural mismatch” (David Chalmers) between our minds and the microstructure of the CNS a real structural mismatch – or an artefact of temporally coarse-grained neuroscanning and perceptual naïve realism?I’m fairly confident that inferential realism is true, as distinct from direct realism or philosophical scepticism.I’m not at all confident non-materialist physicalism is true, though non-materialist physicalism is empirically adequate and potentially falsifiable via interferometry (cf. “Schrödinger's neurons”: If consciousness is fundamental, what predictions does it make?). Alas, it also strains credulity. But then so do eliminativism and dualism. Maybe our entire conceptual scheme is mistaken in ways our minds can’t fathom from within.

Recently Michael Graziano’s theory explains how conscious experience is produced. Earlier and more detailed is Daniel Dennett’s theory. Damasio explains how you can experience your hand via the region of the brain that is dedicated to (and connected to) your hand. To produce conscious experience, you need feedback loops which is why Douglas Hofstadter labeled the necessary feedback mechanisms as a “Strange Loop”. The hard problem, put forward by Chalmers, claims that you build an android that had all of the competence of a human being (walking, thinking, conversation, emotions, etc.) and yet the android would lack conscious experience. That’s an incoherent claim because human competency includes being able to focus attention on yourself and to identify in yourself the causes of your own behavior. This competency is what produces your sense of experience. If an android lacked this capacity it would not appear to be a normally competent human. Graziano’s theory provides the most direct answer to your question. There may be a bell ringing faintly in the distance, but you don’t notice it because your focus of attention is elsewhere. Even so, a scan of your brain would show a brain processes that has done calculations identifying the sound as a bell and even containing the information regarding how many times it has chimed. If someone then asks you what time it is, you suddenly realize the bell has been ringing and can count the number of chimes retroactively. Your sudden focus of attention on the bell requires an additional process in your brain that links a neural representation of the bell to a neural representation of your own focus of attention. Your brain calculates the thought “I hear a bell ringing”. This additional brain process produces the awareness of the bell. Without that, your brain has registered the bell but you don’t realize it.

I have always failed to understand what is supposed to be so mysterious about consciousness. It is one of the functions of the brain. Period. There are many other animals that also experience consciousness. Our sense of experience is not just meditated by our brains. It is also meditated by our organs of external perception (eyes, ears, nose, tongue, skin), as well as organs of internal perception - all the sensory equipment that alerts us to hunger, chills, exhaustion, lack of breath, and many other things. All these senses impinge on the brain, some leading to conscious perceptions, others not accesible to consciousness but still important to the brain's primary activity of keeping us alive. There is no mystical barrier between our lived experience and the external world which we inhabit - the same is true for all other living things. We have experiences of the world around us because we physically interact with it. That sense of experience is just what our brain does, in the same way that pumping blood around the body is what the heart does, and digesting food is what the stomach and intestines do. Nothing difficult to explain, mysterious our problematic about it.

Yes. There are a growing group of experts that are discovering a significant consensus is possible, after all, in the Theories of consciousness topic over at Canonizer. The emerging consensus Representational Qualia Theory is predicting that qualia, like redness, are physical qualities of our knowledge, we can be directly aware of. This is a testable solution which, if borne out by science, will enable us to do things like eff ineffable qualia, and to know that an abstract computer isn’t phenomenally conscious. After all, the abstract word red, isn’t red. In order to know what it means, you need to interpret it back to a set of physical qualities. And it is not the physical qualities the naive are thinking of. It’s not quite right, to ask “what produces experience?” It’s better to ask what physical qualities is consciousness constructed out of? Basically, consciousness is lots of computationally bound elemental physical qualities, like redness and grenness.

The Hard Problem of Consciousness stems from the simple fact that we are using the wrong tools to apprehend consciousness. We’re attempting to use tools that have been developed to apprehend particles, atoms and molecules to apprehend consciousness, and it does not work - which can only be Nature’s way of telling us that we should be looking elsewhere, and use other tools. I’s a bit what would happen if we attempted to measure the length and width of a table, say, with a voltmeter - we couldn’t, and then we’d say ‘there’s a hard problem of table dimensions’. The mere existence of the HPC just shows that we’re using the wrong tools, but we don’t seem to be listening.

There are no complete theories showing how subjective experience perfectly links with change in matter, but there are theories such as that the overall subjective experience is an emergent property of firing neurons linked in networks, with most occurences beneath consciousness, and with feedback loops constantly in play. Evolution has had 3 billion years to create our sensations from matter so it is a bit early for us to have figured it out. The analysis starts with simple organisms interacting with their environment in chemical and electrical ways to sense “prey” vs. “mate” vs. “carnivore” vs. “neutral”. “Light” vs. “dark”, “heat” vs. “cold”, “acid” vs. “base”, etc. with a “self” vs. “other” on-off dichotomy and analog decision-making tree in effect. As organisms develop a nervous system the feedback loop improves learning and analysis and memory and speed. Since we can’t interview other species besides a few chimps with limited language skills we can’t know “what it’s like to be a bat” but can assume some commonalities with species most like us, with various tests like the “mirror test” used to determine self-consciousness, and examination of brain/limbic similarities to our own emotional responses. See Daniel Dennett’s “From Bacteria to Bach” for a latest (mostly) comprehensive attempt by a philosopher.

It is only a hard problem if you believe that matter gave rise to “Consciousness”. Translation The great sage Nārada continued: The living entity acts in a gross body in this life. This body is forced to act by the subtle body, composed of mind, intelligence and ego. After the gross body is lost, the subtle body is still there to enjoy or suffer. Thus there is no change. Purport The living entity has two kinds of body — the subtle body and the gross body. Actually, he enjoys through the subtle body, which is composed of mind, intelligence and ego. The gross body is the instrumental outer covering. When the gross body is lost, or when it dies, the root of the gross body — the subtle body of mind, intelligence and ego — continues and brings about another gross body. Although the gross body apparently changes, the real root of the gross body is always there. The subtle body’s activities, be they pious or impious, create another situation for the living entity to enjoy or suffer in the next gross body. Thus the subtle body continues, whereas the gross bodies change one after another. Since modern scientists and philosophers are too materialistic, and since their knowledge is taken away by the illusory energy, they cannot explain how the gross body is changing. The materialistic philosopher Darwin has tried to study the changes of the gross body, but because he had no knowledge of either the subtle body or the soul, he could not clearly explain how the evolutionary process is going on. One may change the gross body, but he works in the subtle body. People cannot understand the activities of the subtle body, and consequently, they are bewildered as to how the actions of one gross body affect another gross body. The activities of the subtle body are also guided by the Supersoul, as explained in Bhagavad-gītā (15.15): sarvasya cāhaṁ hṛdi sanniviṣṭomattaḥ smṛtir jñānam apohanaṁ ca “I am seated in everyone’s heart, and from Me come remembrance, knowledge, and forgetfulness.” Because the Supreme Personality of Godhead as Supersoul is always guiding the individual soul, the individual soul always knows how to act according to the reactions of his past karma. In other words, the Supersoul reminds him to act in such a way. Therefore although there is apparently a change in the gross body, there is a continuation between the lives of an individual soul. ]

The so-called “hard problem of consciousness” is misconceived. Consciousness is merely the act of paying attention to mental events and that has been pretty well mapped out for decades. What seems mysterious to researchers is the subjective sense that life is happening to “me” and they focus on consciousness because it is such a core aspect of the “me” function.

In a word, no. There is not currently any theoretical framework to even allow us to begin constructing productive hypotheses. We’re still waiting for someone to do for consciousness what Einstein did for gravity.
